Posts.Title: No doctor has seen me since hospital - normal? BustersMom curlieqs

Posts.Content: BustersMom wrote: Surgery was on 7/7, and I was released on 7/11.   My BS saw me on that day - and that's the last time an MD has seen my chest. I had bilateral with SNB & immediate recon. BS said that my primary follow ups would be with the PS.  That made sense, since he "finished" the surgery. I was told to call PS when drains reached 15cc ( unless I had signs of infection). Monday I called & went in for drain removal.  The nurse took care of it for me, and didn't even look at the rest of me until I said "can you please look at my other drain & incisions just to be sure it looks okay"?  She did, and said I'm fine. I was told to call again when the other drain gets low.  And also to schedule a fill for next week. I dunno - this was major surgery, was it not ?  It seems so weird that nobody wants to see me yet. I am seeing BS in a week though.   Is this all normal ??   BMX 7/7/08 (R was prophy), SNB, immed recon. 1st exchange surgery 10/31/08; revision on 2/6/09; Tamoxifen 9/08. Local Recur DX 12/09. Excision and Oophorectomy 2/1/2010. Rads done 4/2010. Dx 5/19/2008, IDC, 1cm, Stage I, Grade 1, 0/4 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Posts.Title: No doctor has seen me since hospital - normal? BustersMom curlieqs

Posts.Content: Jun 21, 2008 05:21AM BustersMom wrote: Hi Stacey, Sorry to hear of your DX - I know that this is a very hard time for you. I'm relatively young (42), BRCA negative, and have multifocal disease (IDC as well) in my left breast.   Since the disease is multi-focal, I am not a candidate for lumpetcomy.  So...  After much contemplation (over the past 5 weeks!) I have decided that I want a bi-lateral mastectomy.  I just decided this 2 days ago.   It's a touch choice to make - and has to be the right, personal decision for you. You'll need to get as much info as you can, and then give yourself a bit of time to make the right decision for you.  Your surgeon/doctor can explain the various options to you.    At first you just wont' know what to do - and then, you will be able to settle down a bit, look at the facts, think about your own peace of mind - and do what's right for YOU. For me, I just don't want to deal with finding another tumor on my right breast.  I found the tumor on my left (mammo missed it).  I dont' want to have MRI's on my right breast every 6 months.  I feel like my right breast is just a time-bomb.  Finally,  I want a symmetrical reconstruction.  Give yourself time to think about it.  I started a thread on the "Surgery" board - it's called "uni-later vs. bi-lasteral - your story?" and everyone's responses are different & very helpful. By the way, I found it funny that yo named your tumor "Sid".  I named mine "Arnold" just after I found it.   Take care, Hugs, Julie

Posts.Content: Feb 20, 2009 11:20PM BustersMom wrote: Hi - I had BC in the left only.  My BRCA came back negative, but I decided to have bilateral anyway.   That was 7 months ago, and there is not one day I regret my decision. It's a very personal choice, and what's right for one person may not be right for the next. I started a thread under "help me get through treatment" & asked people to tell me their story on how they chose between "uni-lateral or bi-lateral - your story?"    That helped me a lot! Best of luck to you.  Whatever you decide - will the the right decision.. for you!!  That's what matters most.

Posts.Title: What to expect with breast MRI? slyspyder Genia

Posts.Content: Dec 11, 2008 08:50PM BustersMom wrote: Hi - my doctor also gave me Lorazepam when I was first DX'd.    It made me pretty sleepy, so I only took it when I was ready for bed.  It definitely helped!!  I had no ill effects (and I'm one of those people who is paranoid about taking new drugs.) It is best to only take it for a very short duration of time;  this medication is highly addictive (in the physical sense).  If you are still apprehensive - do what I did:  Cut a pill up into 1/4's & just take a tiny crumb at first to see how you fare.   Good luck & hugs!! Juliet

Posts.Content: Jul 25, 2008 09:45PM BustersMom wrote: Along with the above items.... I was so glad that I brought:  Baby wipes to clean myself up after using the commode, or just to freshen my skin. A pump jar of hand sanitizer to use before & after eating, using commode, etc.   (Getting to the bathroom was too tough for me the first few days, plus my room mate was always in there.) Stretchy headband was great.  Kept dirty hair off my face & comfy for lying on my back.  Walgreens had cute ones  - 2 for $3.00. Finally I bought a small package of anti-bacterial wipes & had my BF "sanitize" the call button/tv remote, the telephone, and other things that had been touched by zillions of people. Guess I might sound like a germaphobe, but after seeing my mom get a staph infection, I was going to do everything I could to kill germs. Best of luck to Nana!!! :)    Hugs, Julie
